variant.question: What is the correct action to counteract vertigo?

options.text: Believe the instruments.
Concentrate on the vertical speed indicator.
Rely on the information from the semicircular canals, since these will be transmitting correct information.
Reduce rate of breathing until all symptoms disappear, then breathe again normally.

variant.question:
What could the crew do in order to avoid airsickness with passengers?
1) Avoid turbulences.
2) Avoid flying through rough weather.
3) Seat passenger close to the centre of gravity.
4) Give pertinent information.

options.text: 1, 2, 3 and 4 are correct.
3 and 4 are correct, 1 and 2 are false.
1, 2 and 3 are correct, 4 is false.
Only 4 is correct.

variant.question: Which of the following lists is correct concerning the symptoms of motion sickness?

options.text: Apathy, pallor, hyperventilation, nausea, salivation, cold sweats.
Large pupils, dry mouth, annoyance, red face, headache.
Sweating, hubris, headache, nausea.
Salivation or dry mouth, nausea, euphoria, pallor, small pupils.

variant.question: When accelerating forward the otoliths in the utriculus/sacculus will...

options.text: give the illusion of climbing -body tilting backwards, nose of the aircraft going up-.
give the illusion of descending -body tilting downwards, or forwards, nose of the aircraft going down-.
give the illusion of straight and level flight.
give the illusion of banking.

variant.question: What are the symptoms that the aircrew and passengers are most likely to experience during and shortly after a fume event on board an aircraft?

options.text: Irritation in the eyes, nose and air passages, and a possibility of gastrointestinal upset.
Significantly reduced mental and muscle coordination.
Dizziness and tingling of the hands and feet leading to muscle rigidity and possible collapse.
Coughing and choking caused by the inhalation of smoke.

variant.question: During the approach phase, a passenger starts feeling ear pain and advises the cabin crew of this issue. What can the cabin crew do to help the passenger?

options.text: Suggest to the passenger to swallow and make large jaw movements.
Tell the captain to declare a MAYDAY and request an ambulance to wait for the aircraft at the gate.
Ask the pilot to stop the descent.
Get the passenger a sick bag.

variant.question: Which part of the inner ear's vestibular apparatus sense the different kinds of motion of the human body?

options.text: The semicircular canals detect angular acceleration, where as the otolith detect linear acceleration and gravity
The otolith organs detect angular acceleration, where as the semicircular canals detect linear acceleration but not gravity
The semicircular canals sense motion around the roll, pitch and yaw axes, where as the otolith organs detect angular acceleration and gravity
The otolith organs sense motion around the roll, pitch and yaw axes, where as the semicircular canals detect linear acceleration and gravity

variant.question: Symptoms of air sickness include..

options.text: hyperventilation.
heavy-headedness.
hyperactivity.
shivering.

variant.question: The inner ear is able to perceive 1 angular acceleration 2 linear acceleration 3 Noise

options.text: 1 and 2 and 3 are correct
2 and 3 are correct, 1 is false
2 is correct, 1 and 3 are both false
1 and 2 are correct, 3 is false

variant.question: The cupula in the semicircular canal will be bent when a rotation begins. This is because:

options.text: the fluid (endolymph) within the semicircular canal lags behind the accelerated canal walls.
the cupula will stay in place and give the correct impression.
the fluid (endolymph) will precede the accelerated canal walls.
the cupula will bend on constant angular speeds.

variant.question: When stopping the rotation of a spin we have the sensation:

options.text: that we are starting a spin into the opposite direction.
of the sharp dipping of the nose of the aircraft.
of turning in the same direction.
of the immediate stabilization of the aircraft.

variant.question:
Flying a non-pressurised light aircraft at 9000 feet, your passenger develops blue lips
 What action should you take?

options.text: Assuming the passenger is suffering from hypoxia, you reduce altitude and supply him/her with oxygen.
Supply the passenger with extra oxygen, but do not reduce altitude as the partial pressure of oxygen never results in symptoms below 10000 feet.
Assuming the passenger is hyperventilating, you order him/her to stop breathing while you supply additional oxygen.
You attempt to calm the passenger and occupy him/her with suitable tasks.

variant.question: What can be done to overcome the effects of motion sickness?

options.text: Look at some solid point, such as the horizon.
Move your head during aircraft manoeuvres.
During aircraft manoeuvres, place your head against the back of your seat.
When reading a chart, bend forward.

variant.question: What counter-measure can be used against a barotrauma of the middle ear (aerotitis)?

options.text: Close the mouth, pinch the nose tight and blow out thereby increasing the pressure in the mouth and throat. At the same time try to swallow or move lower jaw (Valsalva).
Increase rate of descent.
Pilots should apply anti-cold remedies prior every flight to prevent barotrauma in the middle ear.
Stop climbing, start descent.

variant.question: When an aircraft stops rotating in a spin, those on board will experience the sensation of...

options.text: starting a spin in the opposite direction.
a sharp dipping of the aircraft’s nose.
the immediate stabilisation of the aircraft.
turning in the same direction.

variant.question: The probability to suffer from air sickness is higher when:

options.text: the passenger or student is afraid and/or demotivated to fly.
the student is motivated and adapted to the specific stimuli of flying.
the passenger has taken anti-motion sickness remedies prior flight.
the student has good outside visual reference.

variant.question: Symptoms of motion sickness may be counteracted by..

options.text: fixing one’s gaze on a stable, distant horizon.
resting one’s head on the back of the seat and keeping the eyes open.
increasing head movements to maintain adequate lookout.
bending the head forward when reading maps and checklists.

variant.question:
What do you do, when you are affected by pilot's vertigo?
1) Establish and maintain an effective instrument cross-check.
2) Believe the instruments.
3) Ignore illusions.
4) Minimize head movements.

options.text: 1, 2, 3 and 4 are correct.
Only 4 is false.
1 and 2 are correct, 3 and 4 are false.
1, 2 and 3 are correct, 4 is false.

variant.question: You have just had a close encounter with another aircraft, your heartbeat is racing and your rapid breathing is getting worse. What might you be suffering from?

options.text: Hyperventilation
Hypoventilation
Hypoxia
Hypersensitivity

variant.question: You have just had a close encounter with another aircraft, your heartbeat is racing and your rapid breathing is getting worse. What might you be suffering from?

options.text: Hyperventilation.
Hypersensitivity.
Hypoventilation.
Hypoxia.

The cochlea
The Eustachian tube

options.text: The sacculus and utriculus.

variant.question: What is understood by air sickness?

options.text: A sensory conflict within the vestibular system resulting in nausea and vomiting.
An illness caused by reduced air pressure.
An illness caused by evaporation of gases in the blood.
An illness caused by an infection of the middle ear.

options.text: linear acceleration along all three axes of the body.
linear speeds along all three axes of the aircraft.
angular speeds around the horizontal and vertical axes of the body.
angular accelerations around the horizontal and vertical axes of the aircraft.

options.text: Anxiety
Repeated exposure to flying an aircraft
Reduced sensitivity of the semi-circular canal
Similarity between sensory inputs and terrestrial experiences

gravity.
movements with constant speeds.
relative speed and linear accelerations.

middle ear.

Drink more tea and coffee, but without sugar.
drink water and splash plenty of water on the face.

gives the impression of hearing.

flying at too high altitude without supplemental oxygen.

variant.question: While flying, the captain feels light-headed. He then feels an uncomfortable pressure on his left chest that lasts for a few minutes. All of the sudden, his left arm goes numb.

options.text: The captain should tell the co-pilot about this as soon as possible.
The captain should not tell the co-pilot anything not to worry him/her.
The captain should ask to be pilot monitoring during the approach.
The captain should try not to focus on the pain and attend his AME as soon as they land.
